title: 104_s2088
content: The "Child Care Infrastructure Act of 1996" allows for a credit for employer expenses for child care assistance under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This credit is known as the "Employer-Provided Child Care Credit" (SEC. 45D). The "Employer-Provided Child Care Credit" allows for a credit of 50% of qualified child care expenditures, not exceeding $150,000 per year. Qualified expenditures include costs for property used as a child care facility, not part of the taxpayer's or employee's residence. The "Employer-Provided Child Care Credit" allows for a credit of 50% of qualified child care expenditures, not exceeding $150,000 per year. Qualified expenditures include costs for operating a qualified child care facility, training employees, scholarship programs, increased compensation for employees with child care training, and providing dependent care services or resource and referral services to employees. A qualified child care facility is defined as a facility that meets certain criteria. The term 'qualified child care facility' refers to a facility that primarily offers dependent care assistance and complies with state or local regulations, excluding facilities that are the operator's primary residence. A qualified child care facility must meet certain criteria, including being open to the taxpayer's employees, not being the taxpayer's primary business, and not favoring highly compensated employees. The taxpayer must ensure that the qualified child care facility does not discriminate in favor of highly compensated employees. If there is a recapture event, the taxpayer's tax will be increased based on the applicable recapture percentage and the decrease in credits for prior years. The taxpayer's tax will increase based on the applicable recapture percentage and the decrease in credits for prior years if there is a recapture event related to qualified child care expenditures. The applicable recapture percentage for qualified child care expenditures varies depending on the year of the recapture event, starting at 100% in Years 1-3 and decreasing to 0% in Years 11 and thereafter. A recapture event is defined as a specific event triggering the recapture of credits. The recapture event, as defined in the subsection, includes the cessation of operation or change in ownership of a qualified child care facility. The recapture percentage varies depending on the year of the event, starting at 100% in Years 1-3 and decreasing to 0% in Years 11 and beyond. The recapture liability can be assumed by the new owner of a facility, making them responsible for any tax recapture. Tax liability is increased only for credits used to reduce tax, not for unused credits. The tax liability is increased only for credits used to reduce tax, not for unused credits. Any increase in tax shall not affect the amount of any credit under certain parts of the tax code. The increase in tax does not apply if a qualified child care facility ceases operation due to a casualty loss that is restored by reconstruction or replacement. The tax increase does not apply if a qualified child care facility ceases operation due to a casualty loss that is restored by reconstruction or replacement. Special rules apply for aggregation, pass-thru in estates and trusts, and allocation in partnerships. No double benefit is allowed in reducing basis for the credit. The credit in partnerships is allocated among partners as per regulations. No double benefit is allowed in reducing basis for the credit. The section discusses the recapture of tax credits and the termination of the provision after December 31, 1999. Conforming amendments are made to Section 38(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The text chunk discusses amendments to the employer-provided child care credit, including changes to paragraphs (11) and (12) and the addition of a new paragraph (13). Additionally, a new item is added to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The amendments to the employer-provided child care credit, including changes to paragraphs (11) and (12) and the addition of a new paragraph (13), will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1996.
